defs.docs:
This crate provides a cross platform abstraction for writing colored text to
a terminal. Colors are written using either ANSI escape sequences or by
communicating with a Windows console. Much of this API was motivated by use
inside command line applications, where colors or styles can be configured
by the end user and/or the environment.

attributes.value: deny(missing_docs)

defs.name: WriteColor
defs.docs: This trait describes the behavior of writers that support colored output.

attributes.value: / This trait describes the behavior of writers that support colored output.

defs.name: supports_color
defs.docs: Returns true if and only if the underlying writer supports colors.

attributes.value: / Returns true if and only if the underlying writer supports colors.

defs.name: set_color
defs.docs: Set the color settings of the writer.

attributes.value: / Set the color settings of the writer.
/ Subsequent writes to this writer will use these settings until either
/ `reset` is called or new color settings are set.
/ If there was a problem setting the color settings, then an error is
/ returned.

defs.name: reset
defs.docs: Reset the current color settings to their original settings.

attributes.value: / Reset the current color settings to their original settings.
/ If there was a problem resetting the color settings, then an error is
/ returned.

defs.name: is_synchronous
defs.docs:
Returns true if and only if the underlying writer must synchronously
 interact with an end user's device in order to control colors. By
 default, this always returns `false`.

attributes.value: / Returns true if and only if the underlying writer must synchronously
/ interact with an end user's device in order to control colors. By
/ default, this always returns `false`.
/ In practice, this should return `true` if the underlying writer is
/ manipulating colors using the Windows console APIs.
/ This is useful for writing generic code (such as a buffered writer)
/ that can perform certain optimizations when the underlying writer
/ doesn't rely on synchronous APIs. For example, ANSI escape sequences
/ can be passed through to the end user's device as is.

defs.name: Always
defs.docs:
Try very hard to emit colors. This includes emitting ANSI colors
 on Windows if the console API is unavailable.

attributes.value: / Try very hard to emit colors. This includes emitting ANSI colors
/ on Windows if the console API is unavailable.

defs.name: AlwaysAnsi
defs.docs:
AlwaysAnsi is like Always, except it never tries to use anything other
 than emitting ANSI color codes.

attributes.value: / AlwaysAnsi is like Always, except it never tries to use anything other
/ than emitting ANSI color codes.

defs.name: Auto
defs.docs:
Try to use colors, but don't force the issue. If the console isn't
 available on Windows, or if TERM=dumb, or if `NO_COLOR` is defined, for
 example, then don't use colors.

attributes.value: / Try to use colors, but don't force the issue. If the console isn't
/ available on Windows, or if TERM=dumb, or if `NO_COLOR` is defined, for
/ example, then don't use colors.

defs.name: Never
defs.docs: Never emit colors.

attributes.value: / Never emit colors.

defs.name: ColorChoice
defs.docs: ColorChoice represents the color preferences of an end user.

attributes.value: / ColorChoice represents the color preferences of an end user.

defs.name: StandardStream
defs.docs:
Satisfies `io::Write` and `WriteColor`, and supports optional coloring
 to either of the standard output streams, stdout and stderr.

attributes.value: / Satisfies `io::Write` and `WriteColor`, and supports optional coloring
/ to either of the standard output streams, stdout and stderr.

defs.name: StandardStreamLock
defs.docs: `StandardStreamLock` is a locked reference to a `StandardStream`.

attributes.value: / `StandardStreamLock` is a locked reference to a `StandardStream`.
/ This implements the `io::Write` and `WriteColor` traits, and is constructed
/ via the `Write::lock` method.
/ The lifetime `'a` refers to the lifetime of the corresponding
/ `StandardStream`.

defs.name: BufferedStandardStream
defs.docs: Like `StandardStream`, but does buffered writing.

attributes.value: / Like `StandardStream`, but does buffered writing.

defs.name: stdout
defs.docs:
Create a new `StandardStream` with the given color preferences that
 writes to standard output.

attributes.value: / Create a new `StandardStream` with the given color preferences that
/ writes to standard output.
/ On Windows, if coloring is desired and a Windows console could not be
/ found, then ANSI escape sequences are used instead.
/ The specific color/style settings can be configured when writing via
/ the `WriteColor` trait.

defs.name: stderr
defs.docs:
Create a new `StandardStream` with the given color preferences that
 writes to standard error.

attributes.value: / Create a new `StandardStream` with the given color preferences that
/ writes to standard error.
/ On Windows, if coloring is desired and a Windows console could not be
/ found, then ANSI escape sequences are used instead.
/ The specific color/style settings can be configured when writing via
/ the `WriteColor` trait.

defs.name: lock
defs.docs: Lock the underlying writer.

attributes.value: / Lock the underlying writer.
/ The lock guard returned also satisfies `io::Write` and
/ `WriteColor`.
/ This method is **not reentrant**. It may panic if `lock` is called
/ while a `StandardStreamLock` is still alive.

defs.name: stdout
defs.docs:
Create a new `BufferedStandardStream` with the given color preferences
 that writes to standard output via a buffered writer.

attributes.value: / Create a new `BufferedStandardStream` with the given color preferences
/ that writes to standard output via a buffered writer.
/ On Windows, if coloring is desired and a Windows console could not be
/ found, then ANSI escape sequences are used instead.
/ The specific color/style settings can be configured when writing via
/ the `WriteColor` trait.

defs.name: stderr
defs.docs:
Create a new `BufferedStandardStream` with the given color preferences
 that writes to standard error via a buffered writer.

attributes.value: / Create a new `BufferedStandardStream` with the given color preferences
/ that writes to standard error via a buffered writer.
/ On Windows, if coloring is desired and a Windows console could not be
/ found, then ANSI escape sequences are used instead.
/ The specific color/style settings can be configured when writing via
/ the `WriteColor` trait.

defs.name: BufferWriter
defs.docs: Writes colored buffers to stdout or stderr.

attributes.value: / Writes colored buffers to stdout or stderr.
/ Writable buffers can be obtained by calling `buffer` on a `BufferWriter`.
/ This writer works with terminals that support ANSI escape sequences or
/ with a Windows console.
/ It is intended for a `BufferWriter` to be put in an `Arc` and written to
/ from multiple threads simultaneously.

defs.name: stdout
defs.docs:
Create a new `BufferWriter` that writes to stdout with the given
 color preferences.

attributes.value: / Create a new `BufferWriter` that writes to stdout with the given
/ color preferences.
/ On Windows, if coloring is desired and a Windows console could not be
/ found, then ANSI escape sequences are used instead.
/ The specific color/style settings can be configured when writing to
/ the buffers themselves.

defs.name: stderr
defs.docs:
Create a new `BufferWriter` that writes to stderr with the given
 color preferences.

attributes.value: / Create a new `BufferWriter` that writes to stderr with the given
/ color preferences.
/ On Windows, if coloring is desired and a Windows console could not be
/ found, then ANSI escape sequences are used instead.
/ The specific color/style settings can be configured when writing to
/ the buffers themselves.

defs.name: separator
defs.docs:
If set, the separator given is printed between buffers. By default, no
 separator is printed.

attributes.value: / If set, the separator given is printed between buffers. By default, no
/ separator is printed.
/ The default value is `None`.

defs.name: buffer
defs.docs: Creates a new `Buffer` with the current color preferences.

attributes.value: / Creates a new `Buffer` with the current color preferences.
/ A `Buffer` satisfies both `io::Write` and `WriteColor`. A `Buffer` can
/ be printed using the `print` method.
cfg(not(windows))

defs.name: print
defs.docs: Prints the contents of the given buffer.

attributes.value: / Prints the contents of the given buffer.
/ It is safe to call this from multiple threads simultaneously. In
/ particular, all buffers are written atomically. No interleaving will
/ occur.

defs.name: Buffer
defs.docs: Write colored text to memory.

attributes.value: / Write colored text to memory.
/ `Buffer` is a platform independent abstraction for printing colored text to
/ an in memory buffer. When the buffer is printed using a `BufferWriter`, the
/ color information will be applied to the output device (a tty on Unix and a
/ console on Windows).
/ A `Buffer` is typically created by calling the `BufferWriter.buffer`
/ method, which will take color preferences and the environment into
/ account. However, buffers can also be manually created using `no_color`,
/ `ansi` or `console` (on Windows).

defs.name: no_color
defs.docs: Create a buffer that drops all color information.

attributes.value: / Create a buffer that drops all color information.

defs.name: ansi
defs.docs: Create a buffer that uses ANSI escape sequences.

attributes.value: / Create a buffer that uses ANSI escape sequences.

defs.name: is_empty
defs.docs: Returns true if and only if this buffer is empty.

attributes.value: / Returns true if and only if this buffer is empty.

defs.name: len
defs.docs: Returns the length of this buffer in bytes.

attributes.value: / Returns the length of this buffer in bytes.

defs.name: clear
defs.docs: Clears this buffer.

attributes.value: / Clears this buffer.

defs.name: into_inner
defs.docs: Consume this buffer and return the underlying raw data.

attributes.value: / Consume this buffer and return the underlying raw data.
/ On Windows, this unrecoverably drops all color information associated
/ with the buffer.

defs.name: as_slice
defs.docs: Return the underlying data of the buffer.

attributes.value: / Return the underlying data of the buffer.

defs.name: as_mut_slice
defs.docs: Return the underlying data of the buffer as a mutable slice.

attributes.value: / Return the underlying data of the buffer as a mutable slice.

defs.name: NoColor
defs.docs: Satisfies `WriteColor` but ignores all color options.

attributes.value: / Satisfies `WriteColor` but ignores all color options.

defs.name: new
defs.docs:
Create a new writer that satisfies `WriteColor` but drops all color
 information.

attributes.value: / Create a new writer that satisfies `WriteColor` but drops all color
/ information.

defs.name: into_inner
defs.docs: Consume this `NoColor` value and return the inner writer.

attributes.value: / Consume this `NoColor` value and return the inner writer.

defs.name: get_ref
defs.docs: Return a reference to the inner writer.

attributes.value: / Return a reference to the inner writer.

defs.name: get_mut
defs.docs: Return a mutable reference to the inner writer.

attributes.value: / Return a mutable reference to the inner writer.

defs.name: Ansi
defs.docs: Satisfies `WriteColor` using standard ANSI escape sequences.

attributes.value: / Satisfies `WriteColor` using standard ANSI escape sequences.

defs.name: new
defs.docs:
Create a new writer that satisfies `WriteColor` using standard ANSI
 escape sequences.

attributes.value: / Create a new writer that satisfies `WriteColor` using standard ANSI
/ escape sequences.

defs.docs: Consume this `Ansi` value and return the inner writer.

attributes.value: / Consume this `Ansi` value and return the inner writer.

defs.docs: Return a reference to the inner writer.

attributes.value: / Return a reference to the inner writer.

defs.docs: Return a mutable reference to the inner writer.

defs.docs: A color specification.

attributes.value: / A color specification.

defs.docs: Get whether this is bold or not.

attributes.value: / Get whether this is bold or not.
/ Note that the bold setting has no effect in a Windows console.

defs.value: pub fn set_bold(&mut Self, bool) -> &mut ColorSpec
defs.docs: Set whether the text is bolded or not.

attributes.value: / Set whether the text is bolded or not.
/ Note that the bold setting has no effect in a Windows console.

defs.docs: Get whether this is italic or not.

attributes.value: / Get whether this is italic or not.
/ Note that the italic setting has no effect in a Windows console.

defs.name: set_italic
defs.value: pub fn set_italic(&mut Self, bool) -> &mut ColorSpec
defs.docs: Set whether the text is italicized or not.

attributes.value: / Set whether the text is italicized or not.
/ Note that the italic setting has no effect in a Windows console.

defs.name: underline
defs.docs: Get whether this is underline or not.

attributes.value: / Get whether this is underline or not.
/ Note that the underline setting has no effect in a Windows console.

defs.name: set_underline
defs.value: pub fn set_underline(&mut Self, bool) -> &mut ColorSpec
defs.docs: Set whether the text is underlined or not.

attributes.value: / Set whether the text is underlined or not.
/ Note that the underline setting has no effect in a Windows console.

defs.name: reset
defs.docs: Get whether reset is enabled or not.

attributes.value: / Get whether reset is enabled or not.
/ reset is enabled by default. When disabled and using ANSI escape
/ sequences, a "reset" code will be emitted every time a `ColorSpec`'s
/ settings are applied.
/ Note that the reset setting has no effect in a Windows console.

defs.name: set_reset
defs.value: pub fn set_reset(&mut Self, bool) -> &mut ColorSpec
defs.docs: Set whether to reset the terminal whenever color settings are applied.

attributes.value: / Set whether to reset the terminal whenever color settings are applied.
/ reset is enabled by default. When disabled and using ANSI escape
/ sequences, a "reset" code will be emitted every time a `ColorSpec`'s
/ settings are applied.
/ Typically this is useful if callers have a requirement to more
/ scrupulously manage the exact sequence of escape codes that are emitted
/ when using ANSI for colors.
/ Note that the reset setting has no effect in a Windows console.

defs.name: intense
defs.docs: Get whether this is intense or not.

attributes.value: / Get whether this is intense or not.
/ On Unix-like systems, this will output the ANSI escape sequence
/ that will print a high-intensity version of the color
/ specified.
/ On Windows systems, this will output the ANSI escape sequence
/ that will print a brighter version of the color specified.

defs.name: set_intense
defs.value: pub fn set_intense(&mut Self, bool) -> &mut ColorSpec
defs.docs: Set whether the text is intense or not.

attributes.value: / Set whether the text is intense or not.
/ On Unix-like systems, this will output the ANSI escape sequence
/ that will print a high-intensity version of the color
/ specified.
/ On Windows systems, this will output the ANSI escape sequence
/ that will print a brighter version of the color specified.

defs.name: is_none
defs.docs: Returns true if this color specification has no colors or styles.

attributes.value: / Returns true if this color specification has no colors or styles.

defs.name: clear
defs.docs: Clears this color specification so that it has no color/style settings.

attributes.value: / Clears this color specification so that it has no color/style settings.

defs.name: Color
defs.value:
pub enum Color {
    Black,
    Blue,
    Green,
    Red,
    Cyan,
    Magenta,
    Yellow,
    White,
    Ansi256(u8),
    Rgb(u8, u8, u8),

    #[doc(hidden)]
    __Nonexhaustive,
}
defs.docs: The set of available colors for the terminal foreground/background.

attributes.value: / The set of available colors for the terminal foreground/background.
/ The `Ansi256` and `Rgb` colors will only output the correct codes when
/ paired with the `Ansi` `WriteColor` implementation.
/ The `Ansi256` and `Rgb` color types are not supported when writing colors
/ on Windows using the console. If they are used on Windows, then they are
/ silently ignored and no colors will be emitted.
/ This set may expand over time.
/ This type has a `FromStr` impl that can parse colors from their human
/ readable form. The format is as follows:
/ 1. Any of the explicitly listed colors in English. They are matched
/    case insensitively.
/ 2. A single 8-bit integer, in either decimal or hexadecimal format.
/ 3. A triple of 8-bit integers separated by a comma, where each integer is
/    in decimal or hexadecimal format.
/ Hexadecimal numbers are written with a `0x` prefix.
allow(missing_docs)

defs.name: ParseColorError
defs.docs: An error from parsing an invalid color specification.

attributes.value: / An error from parsing an invalid color specification.

defs.name: invalid
defs.docs: Return the string that couldn't be parsed as a valid color.

attributes.value: / Return the string that couldn't be parsed as a valid color.
